abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is rated satisfactory,
            with project sustainability likely. The Bank responded
            quickly to address the urgent rehabilitation needs of the
            sector. With continuous security concerns and extended
            border closures, implementation delays were inevitable.
            However, despite  the continuous threat and instability,
            close monitoring of the implementation activities ultimately
            led to the  completion of all the major components. All
            through the implementation period, the Bank was flexible;
            this  demonstrated adequate responsiveness towards
            Borrower's changing needs and priorities. Reallocation
            of  funds between components and between other projects (in
            the same sector) were formalized whenever  necessary.
            Although the effectiveness of the institutional
            strengthening component was modest with  regards to building
            the Palestinian water Authority's (PWA) regulatory
            capacity, adequate support through the provision of
            necessary technical assistance  ultimately helped in
            creation of a solid project management unit and in the
            adoption of the new Water Law that led to the  creation of
            the Water and Wastewater Company for Gaza. Finally, the
            overall project framework created  the necessary environment
            for other donors to provide much needed funds for the
            sector. In view of the  above, the overall Bank performance
            is considered to be highly satisfactory. Overall borrower
            performance was highly satisfactory. Some of the lessons
            learned included the following: 1) Borrower's strong
            commitment for development of the sector  through the
            Project was a key factor that not only helped formulate the
            Project concept/design but also  facilitated its
            implementation at every successive stage. 2) In Gaza, where
            no regulatory capacity existed before the management
            contract  went into effect, the contracting of an
            independent reputable auditing firm proved to be essential
            in  building trust between the public and private parties
            involved. 3) The management contract experience in Gaza,
            suggests that providing higher  degrees of management
            responsibility to the operator can expedite system improvements.
